channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Storm Brings Flooding and Destruction to Sardinia
item.description: The Italian government declared a state of emergency on the island on Tuesday after a torrential rainstorm killed at least 16 people.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Firefighters rescued a man during flash flooding on Tuesday in Terralba, Sardinia.

item.title: South Africa Building Site Collapses
item.description: Up to 50 construction workers are trapped under rubble after a half-built shopping center collapsed near the South African coastal city of Durban, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Emergency workers searched for survivors after a building collapsed near the South African coastal city of Durban on Tuesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: Josef Koudelka: Formed by the World
item.description: Josef Koudelka has traveled the globe, photographing on his own terms. But as he puts the world in his viewfinder, the world shapes him in return.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Blasts at Iranian Embassy in Beirut Kill at Least 23
item.description: The attack, which killed at least 23 people, including an Iranian diplomat, seemed to fit a pattern of deepening political and sectarian division across the region inspired by the civil war in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD, ANNE BARNARD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Key Issue Said to Be Resolved in U.S.-Afghan Security Talks
item.description: Afghan officials said a long-term security pact could be reached with the United States if President Obama acknowledged military mistakes and vowed not to repeat them.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: An image of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on a building in the center of Kabul, on Tuesday.

item.title: Yangon Journal: As Myanmar Modernizes, Old Professions Go the Way of the Typewriter
item.description: Businesses are forced to adapt, or risk disappearing, in a country where the pace of change has been compressed into months, not decades.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: David Høgsholt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Typewriter clerks who sit outside courthouses and government offices are losing ground to computers and email.

item.title: With Bomb and Then Guns, Shabab Strikes a Somali Police Station
item.description: At least 28 people were killed and many were wounded when the militant group staged an attack in Beledweyne, near the Ethiopian border.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM and NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: For Philippine Children, Return of Play Is a Sign of Hope
item.description: While food and water remain scarce more than a week after Typhoon Haiyan, aid groups have begun setting up areas where children can try to have a little fun.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan played on swings at a devastated area of Basey, north of Tacloban, on Tuesday.

item.title: The Lede: Toronto Mayor Knocks Over City Council Member at Meeting
item.description: Mayor Rob Ford knocked over a City Council member during a tense special session called to debate a motion that would strip him of almost all mayoral powers.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Israel Rejects Bid to Free Suspected Qaeda Operative
item.description: Israel’s Supreme Court ruled that a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian detainee held for more than three years without trial was too dangerous to release.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 19
item.description: Bharatiya Mahila Bank is India’s first state owned women’s bank.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women at the inauguration of Bharatiya Mahila Bank, India's first state owned women's bank, in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: At War Blog: Waging War on a Shoestring
item.description: The theme at a conference on security challenges was self-inflicted wounds to military readiness.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: Memo From France: Hollande’s Assertive Role in Foreign Policy Is a Good Fit for France
item.description: President François Hollande of France is building a far more confident image abroad than at home, a striking contrast that shows how much his nation values a role in world affairs.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President François Hollande, left, at the Hall of Remembrance at the Yad Vashem Holocaust museum in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: Pushing Peace on the Palestinians
item.description: Omer Barlev, an opposition lawmaker, is pushing for a unilateral solution to the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian conflict that would leave the Palestinians out of the process.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Offers Hospital Ship to the Philippines
item.description: Widespread criticism of China’s slow response to the devastation in the Philippines from Typhoon Haiyan has awakened the Chinese authorities to the damage done to the country’s image.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Officers in Myanmar bidding farewell to the Chinese hospital ship Peace Ark in September.

item.title: India Ink: Guwahati’s Cosmetic Development
item.description: The author writes about the changes that his hometown has undergone over the years.
item.dc:creator: By ARUNI KASHYAP
item.media:description: Police personnel patrolling the banks of Brahmaputra River ahead of Republic Day celebrations in Guwahati, Assam, on Jan. 23, 2009.

item.title: Nepal Holds Vote Amid Scattered Violence
item.description: Maoists in two areas disrupted the election of a body charged with writing a constitution, but the majority of citizens are said to have cast ballots.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Chinese Nobel Winner Appealing Subversion Conviction
item.description: A court in Beijing sentenced Liu Xiaobao to 11 years in prison for advocating wide-ranging political changes that sought greater democracy.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another Animated Take on Bloomberg News
item.description: The suspension of a prize-winning reporter has provided more inspiration for the animators at Next Media of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Country at a Crossroads: In Middle of Mexico, a Middle Class Rises
item.description: In the mostly poor state of Guanajuato, long known as one of the country’s main sources of illegal immigrants to the United States, a new Mexico has begun to emerge.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: India’s Chief Climate Change Negotiator Ravi Shankar Prasad
item.description: Mr. Prasad spoke about India’s expectations from the annual United Nations climate change conference in Warsaw, Poland.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Ravi Shankar Prasad, India's chief climate change negotiator, in Warsaw, Poland.

item.title: His Honor? Toronto’s Mayor Rampages On, to City’s Shame
item.description: Despite the bizarre antics of Mayor Rob Ford, most notably his use of crack, he will likely remain at the helm of Canada’s largest city until his term ends next year.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto at a council meeting on Monday.

item.title: Casting Light on Little-Known Story of Albania Rescuing Jews From Nazis
item.description: A national creed called besa obligates Albanians to provide shelter and safe passage for anyone seeking protection.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:description: Arsllan Rezniqi rode in the back of a car used to transport Jews from Nazi-occupied Macedonia to safe hide-outs. A truck was also used and over time, Mr. Rezniqi moved 400 Jews to Decan, in Kosovo.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Stop Animal Circus Shows, Advocates Tell Government
item.description: Animal rights advocates are trying to stop performances by Bengal tigers, Asian elephants and chimpanzees at a major, government-backed circus show, saying they are cruel.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: An elephant kneeling as children take turns sitting on it at a circus in Beijing.

item.title: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
item.description: The disagreement between American and Israeli leaders over a proposed deal to freeze Iran’s nuclear program is about more than negotiating tactics — it reflects a clash of fundamental goals.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Hamid Foroutan/Iranian Students News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A heavy-water nuclear reactor near the town of Arak, if operating, could provide Iran with a steady supply of plutonium, the fuel North Korea and Pakistan have used for their arsenals.
